title: Mother shares distressing photo of special needs daughter crying outside school as strikes leave her unable to cope

A fed-up mother says her special needs daughter can no longer cope with the stress caused by strikes at her school - sharing a snap that shows the girl in tears. 
Charlotte Gun took the photo of her distraught daughter, Katie-Ann Boyle, 15, who had tears running down her face, after arriving at school to collect her. 
She decided to share the photo on Facebook along with a message describing how strikes by certain staff members, including teaching assistants who help pupils with special needs, have affected Katie-Ann. 
Mrs Gunn, 33, told the Derby Telegraph that teaching assistants are the "backbone" of special needs education, and blasted council bosses over cuts because her daughter's needs at school are "not being met". Katie-Ann with her parents and three siblings (Photo: Charlotte Gunn) Read More Mum home-schools her children by letting them play computer games for SEVEN HOURS a day 
Strikes have been taking place in a number of schools in Derby since last July as teaching assistants, caretakers, lunchtime supervisors and administration staff down tools. 
Some of the strikes have been for half days or lunchtimes but on Tuesday there was a full day of action, which will be repeated on Thursday. 
Parents, mainly of children with special needs whose schools have been hit the hardest by the action, took to the Council House steps last week to protest over the continuing strikes. 
Mrs Gunn, who lives in Chaddesden, Derby, with her husband and four children, said: "The strikes have taken a toll on my daughter. 
"We don't have anything against the teaching assistants because without them she wouldn't be half the little girl that she is today. 
"The children are being denied the education because of the council cuts." 
The council claims it had to carry out the fair pay review in line with national guidelines but Unison has said the authority did not have to make changes to terms and conditions, leading to some support staff losing between £350 to £450 a month. Katie-Ann's mum described how the strikes have affected her (Photo: Charlotte Gunn) Read More Psychologist's warning to mum who home-schools her children by letting them play on computers for seven hours a day 
The row is becoming increasingly bitter and despite both sides indicating they are willing to return to the negotiating table, there is no sign of this happening. 
The council has said it cannot afford the £4m it claims it will cost to accede to the union's demands and Unison has rejected an alternative £1.1m solution. 
Mrs Gunn's Facebook post states: "Collecting my daughter from school to be confronted with her in this state because she can't handle the disruption to her routine. Our special-needs children rely on their teaching assistants – they are the backbone of special needs schooling. 
"Without them many needs of our children can't be met. According to the council the strikes are having little or no effect. 
"Try telling that to my child, I've had to comfort the entire way home because she can't understand what is happening. 
"I guess the strikes just don't affect the schools that matter. But my daughter's education counts, too, maybe not (to the council) but to her and us it's her future." 
She said in sharing the photo of Katie-Ann, who has a range of complex needs which include severe learning difficulties, she is giving her daughter a voice because she is not able to speak for herself. 
Mrs Gunn added: "Because of her special needs she cannot cope with having no routine. All I can do is support the teaching assistants as much as possible by sharing the stories." 
Unison has called three more full days of strikes next week.
